definitions.definition: to move through water by moving your arms and legs, without touching the bottom
definitions.labels: (British English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: I can't swim.
The boys swam across the lake.
We swam out *(= away from land)* to the yacht.
They spent the day swimming and sunbathing.
I've only just learned to swim.
I have always found it easy to swim underwater.
They are too far out to swim to shore.
Can you swim backstroke yet?
How long will it take her to swim the Channel?
Exhausted, they swam ashore.
He can't swim well.
to swim in the sea

definitions.definition: to spend time swimming for pleasure

examples.text: I go swimming twice a week.
We always went swimming together in our indoor pool.

definitions.definition: to move through or across water

examples.text: Sharks must swim or die.
A shoal of fish swam past.
Ducks were swimming around on the river.
A beaver swam vigorously upstream.

definitions.definition: to be covered with a lot of liquid

examples.text: The main course was swimming in oil.
Her eyes were swimming with tears.

definitions.definition: to seem to be moving around, especially when you are ill or drunk

examples.text: The pages swam before her eyes.

definitions.definition: to feel confused and/or as if everything is turning round and round

examples.text: His head swam and he swayed dizzily.

definitions.definition: to be in a situation where you will either succeed by your own efforts or fail completely

examples.text: The new students were just left to sink or swim.
In a situation like this, you either sink or swim.

wordOrigin: Old English swimman (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zwemmen and German schwimmen.
